title: 104_hr3810
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lumbee Recognition Act". The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to recognize the Lumbee Indians of North Carolina as descendants of coastal tribes, recognized by the state since 1885, seeking federal recognition since 1888, and entitled to federal recognition. The Lumbee Indians are entitled to Federal recognition as an Indian tribe and the benefits that come with it. Federal recognition is extended to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, allowing them to receive benefits and services available to Indian tribes. Other Indian groups in the area can seek acknowledgment of tribal existence through a petition process. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is granted federal recognition, making them eligible for services and benefits available to federally recognized Indian tribes. Services will be provided upon the appropriation of funds, and a tribal roll verification will determine the budget needed for these services in consultation with the tribe. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is authorized to plan, conduct, and administer programs and services under the Snyder Act through an annual funding agreement with the Secretaries of the Interior and Health and Human Services. The agreement specifies services, functions, and budget allocations within each fiscal year. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina can modify budget allocations within a fiscal year. The Secretary of the Interior is responsible for auditing the tribe's expenditures. This authority is instead of the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. Sovereign immunity of the tribe is not affected, and the trust responsibility of the United States is not terminated. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina has the authority to modify budget allocations within a fiscal year. The Secretary of the Interior audits the tribe's expenditures, maintaining the tribe's sovereign immunity and the trust responsibility of the United States. After the Secretary verifies the tribal roll, the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina must adopt a constitution and bylaws consistent with the Act. The Secretary will assist in drafting these documents and reorganizing the tribe's government. Only adult enrolled members are eligible for these processes. Only adult enrolled members of the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina can vote on the constitution. The tribe's membership will initially consist of individuals on the tribal roll at the time of the Act's enactment. Within 60 days, the roll will be open for 180 days for enrollment of individuals from other Indian groups in the area who meet specific criteria. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina will advertise the opening of the tribal roll for enrollment. The review of the tribal roll will verify compliance with membership criteria stated in the tribe's petition for Federal Acknowledgment. The Secretary will complete the review within a 12-month period. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina will open the tribal roll for enrollment to verify compliance with membership criteria for Federal Acknowledgment within a 12-month period. An interim government will oversee the process. The Lumbee Regional Development Association (LRDA) is recognized as the provisional governing body of the tribe until a new constitution is adopted. During this period, the LRDA has the authority to enter into contracts with federal agencies and administer programs. Until the election of tribal officers under the new constitution, the LRDA will oversee tribal operations. The LRDA is responsible for overseeing the drafting and proposal of a new constitution for the tribe, opening the tribal roll, advertising the opening, and conducting the election to adopt the constitution. The jurisdiction. The State of North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on lands owned by the Lumbee Tribe. The Secretary of the Interior can accept jurisdiction transfers from the state to the United States after consulting with the Attorney General. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina may transfer jurisdiction to the United States after 2 years. This does not affect the Indian Child Welfare Act. The Act of June 18, 1934, and the Act of April 11, 1970, apply to the tribe for lands in Robeson and adjoining counties. Authorization of appropriations is granted under this Act, allowing necessary funds to be appropriated for its implementation. In the first fiscal year of funding, the tribe must submit expenditure proposals to the Senate's Committee on Indian Affairs and the House of Representatives' Committee on Resources 60 days before spending any allocated funds.
